Just a reminder there are 2,000 Bradley IFVs in storage (which could have been sent to Ukraine months ago), which would be a massive upgrade to Ukrainian mechanized forces and much better than sending Soviet-built tanks that have built-in turret-launching bulleyes or crappy BMPs. Just because the Ukrainians know how to use them doesn't mean it's the best option, sending Bradleys is the much better option. The Bradley is ideal for Ukraine because:

* There's thousands of them already built, paid for, and ready to go. So might as well get your money out of them by having them destroy Russian forces that they were originally designed to destroy.

* There are robust supply chains to Europe already- and somewhat to Ukraine (M270 MLRS is the same chassis and because of that Ukraine already has experience maintaining most of the mechanical parts).

* Ukraine already has experience with anti-tank TOW missiles and TOW missiles on Bradleys destroyed more Soviet-made Iraqi tanks than did Abrams tanks did.

* 25mm cannon is effective against everything else. Armor piercing rounds have been reported to have destroyed T-72 tanks.

* It's lightweight enough to traverse most bridges, can ford up to about waist height, and is amphibious with preparation

* It has ~0.5-0.75 of the ground pressure of an M1 Abrams or T90.

* Boring V8 diesel engine means generic automotive maintenance skills overlap reasonably well, a fraction of the fuel required vs a MBT.

* Obviously it's an infantry carrier so it can carry troops/supplies, plus I'm sure Ukrainian infantry would appreciate armored mobility and protection from artillery. There are also many variants including air defense.

* They're far better than M113s and other lightly armored APCs already sent and better than the Soviet vehicles that Ukraine already use. Soviets cut corners building them to overwhelm NATO through sheer numbers. So a lot of Soviet equipment is of poor quality.

last_replies.com:
>>56195026
>how shitty is this ammo compared to 556 nato
As a caliber, it isn't significantly worse or better than 5.56mm. It was designed largely in response to observing the M16 in use.
The only design characteristic that stands out to me is that it's more tapered than 5.56mm is, which is good for extraction and somewhat of a necessity given that most ammunition for this caliber is steel cased. It's still significantly less tapered than 7.62x39mm so you don't get as much magazine curve which is a minor improvement.

In terms of the ammunition available, there is far less variety than either 5.56mm or 7.62x39mm because it hasn't been around as long or been used by as many people. It's also less common on civilian markets. there is some variety out there, but the vast majority of it is 7N6. The 7N6 loading is pretty clever and offers a good compromise between penetration and terminal performance, but it is also meant for cheap large scale production so it's not exactly meant for precision. Not a bad shooter though.
>is it more inaccurate than akm 762?
Far from it, most 5.45 guns tend to shoot better. It has a flatter trajectory, less recoil and thus it's easier to shoot it well.
>should we be worried?
Why would you be worried? Are you being conscripted and issued an AK-74? If so, it's a perfectly fine rifle but if you're being conscripted into the Russian military you are probably going to have a lot of things to worry about it. The 74 being a bad rifle is thankfully not one of those things.

If you are a civilian in the US buying one, ammunition availability kinda sucks but it's not complete unobtanium.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56195026

My 74 is significantly more pleasant to shoot than my AKM and more fun than my AR. The 74 muzzle brake is very well designed for the platform, there is basically no recoil, it doesn't have that over-pressure face slap like 7.62, and you get that satisfying AK bolt cycle that you don't get with an AR. As far as 5.45, you won't find the same variety in ammo as 5.56. It'll almost be all steel core, steel cased so no firing it at your local indoor range. That also means barrel life is somewhat reduced. My understanding is that it was designed to get better ballistics out of a shorter barrel (16.1") than the 5.56 (20" for the original M16). All the old surplus 74 mags have run dry, but 5.45 PMAGs are cheap. you can even get an AR mag adapter and use AR mags if you cut the follower.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: 5.45 vs NATO 5.56 is kinda superior ballistically but its numbers autism shit that doesn't really pan out to any superior edge in battle especially since the people with 5.56 often have far superior targeting systems.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56195026
5.45x39mm is closely comparable to 5.56x45mm, extremely similar projectile weight, size, and velocities (though typically with different projectile designs). The case of the 5.45mm is more tapered as that works better with the AK, and especially if you're making the casings out of steel like is usually done in Eastern Europe still.

The thought process behind the design was largely "What if Kalashnikov but it shoots cartridge like M16?" and that's pretty much what you have. Having less recoil and a flatter trajectory, it's easier to shoot than 7.62x39mm, though perhaps doesn't penetrate light barriers quite as well.

End of Black Friday deals edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

threads.com: What’s the most likely SHTF scenario?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I live in Finland.
The most likely SHTF scenario is major collapse of society in Russia, which sends huge waves of refugees over our eastern border.

Vast hordes of unemployed russians homeless on streets, trying all sorts of fucked up banditry or begging, whoring, scamming, burglary or trying to sell you krokodil or something.

Luckily we have been preparing for such scenario ever since soviet union collapsed, so there are procedures at place on how to deal with the situation. Probably hard closing border, and corralling the ruskies to immigration camps, police forces beefed up with military troops to maintain order or something. I am not in the know for how it would actually go.

But for some time, moving outside might be a bit more dangerous. And you would have to keep guard if you are a homeowner so someone doesn't try to break into your carage or something. You really couldn't leave a house empty for long periods.

I don't really see a possibility of Russia doing something militarily. They don't have the capacity for it. Most of their active fighting units are firmly in ukraine or belarus, and the bases near Finnish border are on skeleton crew only. Right now, they couldn't muster up a fighting force that we couldn't handle. And then there is the NATO security guarantees, so I don't think that's a likely scenario. They are more dangerous to us when they fuck up their own affairs, than when they try to fuck up ours.

Other than that, the usual SHTF subjects like major general strikes, industrial accidents, extreme weather blocking roads and cutting power etc. These we can deal with, we are well prepared for that shit.

>Me? I like lever guns because of simplicity, reliability, they're traditional and fun to shoot!
>What? Single shot rifles? Disgusting! How could anyone like those things?!
Why are people like this? Literally every reason for preferring repeaters over autos/gas guns, can be applied to preferring single shots over repeaters. There's just something about cracking the breech block open, or breaking the gun in half, and pulling out the spent round that will (to me) always be more fun then simply racking a lever. Not to mention they're even shorter, even lighter, more simpler and more reliable than repeaters.

Unless your goal is to kill lots of humans in a short time, a single shot will suit you far better than a repeater or an autoloader. Simply put, there were too many compromises made to make guns into weapons of war.

For me, it's single shots.

>>56195556
>556 digits kek
That gives you a fair bit of wiggle room and you've got a few options. You're gonna have to think about what you're going to use it for more often - hunting or plinking or range shooting - and kind of weight your decision in that direction because a rifle that's best set up for shooting small groups is probably going to be a cunt of a thing to carry around for a long time, whereas something feather light and easy to carry and shoot rabbits won't necessarily be the best for pushing .223 out to 600 or 700m.

Some basic starting places:
Tikka T3X - there's a big swathe of options here between stock type, barrel profile, overall weight. If you want something that's mostly for the range if you shop around you can probably squeak in on a CTR and an optic, although typically it's kind of the done thing to suggest that you spend half your budget on glass

As the kiwi anon said, Howa 1500s are supposed to be exceptional value, and leave you a lot of room for your optics budget. You can get a chassis variant in a lower-priced MDT chassis that will make life easier for target shooting and that aren't overly more expensive.

Bergara B14s are becoming quite popular. They sit in an R700 footprint so there's an utter fuckload of chassis, triggers, and other accessories available, they're quite good on the accuracy front too.

Ruger American/Predator. Again, good on value, and the Predator can take AR PMags if that's useful.

If you're leaning more towards memey fun, if you're lucky and quick you might find a secondhand Warwick WFA-1 or WFA-1L inside that budget, and depending on how lucky that might include some kind of optic.

Southern Cross Small Arms has a new addition in the meme-gun department, the Taipan - it's a .223 pump action that is vaguely AR shaped and takes PMags. They're selling at dealers for about $2200
with a cheap red dot but they have a pretty long waiting list and we don't know if they're good or shit yet.

I will start: Storm of Steel (in German: In Stahlgewittern, lit.'In Steel Thunderstorms'; original English title: In Storms of Steel) is the memoir of German officer Ernst Jünger's experiences on the Western Front during the First World War from December 1914 to August 1918.

> The book is a graphic account of trench warfare. It was largely devoid of editorialization when first published, but was heavily revised several times. The book established Jünger's fame as a writer in the 1920s. The judgment of contemporaries and later critics reflects the ambivalence of the work, which describes the war in all its brutality, but neither expressly condemns it nor goes into its political causes. It can be read affirmatively, neutrally or as an anti-war book.

Why I recommend it: Its accurately describes how the war actually was, all the details. Very very good read.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Obscure aircraft confrontations/incidents (and Cooper's misreporting on them)
threads.com:
Alright, so I'm really interested in obscure, anecdotal military air confrontations and incidents, and used to read a lot of Tom Cooper, and I mean a LOT of Tom Cooper.
However, I've been noticing overtime that several incidents and anecdotes he mentions in his books and articles have the details skewed, and I wanted to go over the ones I've found for two reasons,
1. After enough of them, you start wondering about his competence and/or integrity
2. They're interesting even with accurate details. I'll provide greentexts for two of these stories with all research I've done after I detail the places he fucked up in.

First is an incident where Talibs shot down an Uzbek Su-24 Fencer.
https://web.archive.org/web/20130921144724/http://www.acig.org/artman/publish/article_339.shtml
In this older acig article, he says the Fencer was shot down on June 6th, 2001. However, looking for more details, I tracked down a copy of the August 2000 edition of Air Forces Monthly, and found it was June 6th/7th, 2000.
Sadly this possible typo confused the author Lukas Muller, who stated the incorrect 2001 date on page 58 of his book Wings Over the Hindu Kush: Air Forces, Aircraft and Air Warfare of Afghanistan, 1989-2001, citing Cooper's article on page 71.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56194867
Just a reminder there are 2,000 Bradley IFVs in storage (which could have been sent months ago), which would be a massive upgrade to Ukrainian mechanized forces and much better than sending Soviet-built tanks that have built-in turret-launching bulleyes or crappy BMPs. Just because the Ukrainians know how to use them doesn't mean it's the best option, sending Bradleys is the much better option. The Bradley is ideal for Ukraine because:

* There's thousands of them already built, paid for, and ready to go. So might as well get your money out of them by having them destroy Russian forces that they were originally designed to destroy.

* There are robust supply chains to Europe already- and somewhat to Ukraine (M270 MLRS is the same chassis and because of that Ukraine already has experience maintaining most of the mechanical parts).

* Ukraine already has experience with anti-tank TOW missiles and TOW missiles on Bradleys destroyed more Soviet-made Iraqi tanks than did Abrams tanks did.

* 25mm cannon is effective against everything else. Armor piercing rounds have been reported to have destroyed T-72 tanks.

* It's lightweight enough to traverse most bridges, can ford up to about waist height, and is amphibious with preparation

* It has ~0.5-0.75 of the ground pressure of an M1 Abrams or T90.

* Boring V8 diesel engine means generic automotive maintenance skills overlap reasonably well, a fraction of the fuel required vs a MBT.

* Obviously it's an infantry carrier so it can carry troops/supplies, plus I'm sure Ukrainian infantry would appreciate armored mobility and protection from artillery. There are also many variants including air defense.

* They're far better than M113s and other lightly armored APCs already sent and better than the Soviet vehicles that Ukraine already use. Soviets cut corners building them to overwhelm NATO through sheer numbers. So a lot of Soviet equipment is of poor quality.

Several factors.
Patrol arrives fucking fast because they only have to come from a local station, and 50% of the time they're closer to the incident then the station.
SWAT are dispatched from a central area, so are driving longer.

SWAT aren't permanently mounted, as they could be called 24/7.
In some places these guys work shifts, in others the poor fucks just get woken up, in some the SWAT isn't a dedicated detail and the same guys will be doing armed response/ active shooter or officer under fire. There is one misconception about rocketry and nazis, especially Von Braun. Before the space race he wasn't very involved in the US rocketry development and he was largely working on liquid fueled rockets, so the claim that he or German scientists are responsible for US ICBM developments are largely unfounded. Of course some knowledge would be applied to new missiles from older liquid fuel ones however by and large US solid fuel developments are the product of American industry and engineering.
